title: The Erdős-Gyárfás Function f(n,4,5)
description: Minimum colors to edge-color Kₙ so every K₄ has ≥5 colors among its 6 edges. Answer: f(n) ~ (5/6)n. Erdős-Gyárfás bounds: (5/6)(n-1) < f(n) < n. Resolved by Bennett et al. (2022).

meta.author: Erdős-Gyárfás (original), Bennett-Cushman-Dudek-Pralat (2022), Joos-Mubayi (2022)
originalContributions: Lean formalization of edge coloring constraints
Definition of f(n,4,5) as minimum satisfying K₄ constraint
Explanation of why 5/6 arises (K₄ has 6 edges, need 5 colors)

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Gyárfás asked for the minimum colors to edge-color Kₙ so every K₄ uses at least 5 of its 6 edges distinctly colored. They proved bounds and Erdős conjectured the lower bound was tight. This was confirmed by Bennett et al. (2022) and independently by Joos-Mubayi.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(n) be the smallest number of colors needed to color edges of Kₙ such that every K₄ contains at least 5 different colors. Determine f(n).
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines edge colorings, the constraint 'every K₄ has ≥5 colors', and states f(n) as the minimum. The asymptotic f(n) ~ (5/6)n is axiomatized from the 2022 results.
keyInsights: K₄ has C(4,2) = 6 edges, requiring ≥5 colors means at most 1 repeated color
The fraction 5/6 naturally arises as 1 - 1/6 (one 'defect' allowed)
Bennett et al. and Joos-Mubayi proved f(n) ~ (5/6)n - the lower bound is tight

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #136 is SOLVED. The Erdős-Gyárfás function f(n,4,5) satisfies f(n) ~ (5/6)n, confirming Erdős's intuition that the lower bound is tight. The constant 5/6 reflects that K₄ has 6 edges and we require 5 colors.
conclusion.implications: This result settles a fundamental question in Ramsey-type graph coloring. The techniques developed connect graph coloring to hypergraph matchings.
openQuestions: What is the exact second-order term in f(n) = (5/6)n + o(n)?
What are the asymptotics for general f(n,p,q)?
Can the hypergraph matching technique extend to other Ramsey problems?
